byline.contributor: Nicholas Kulish reported from Düsseldorf, and Nicola Clark from Paris. Melissa Eddy contributed reporting from Düsseldorf, and Aurelien Breeden from Marseille, France.
byline.original: By NICHOLAS KULISH and NICOLA CLARK

abstract: Investigators are trying to understand what caused German co-pilot Andreas Lubitz to make fateful decision to fly Germanwings jetliner into mountainside in French Alps; their three main lines of inquiry are his apparent bouts depression, eyesight problem, and his personal relationships.
lead_paragraph: Investigators are trying to understand what drove Andreas Lubitz, who was at the controls of the jetliner that crashed in France last week, to the apparent decision to fly into a mountainside.

headline.main: Germanwings Crash Investigators Sorting Through Physical and Psychological Clues
headline.print_headline: Crash Investigators Sorting Through Physical and Psychological Clues

snippet: Investigators are trying to understand what drove Andreas Lubitz, who was at the controls of the jetliner that crashed in France last week, to the apparent decision to fly into a mountainside.
